docs.abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on living up to ethical veganism, discovering your sibling’s progeny on Ancestry.com and faking religious belief.
docs.snippet: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on living up to ethical veganism, discovering your sibling’s progeny on Ancestry.com and faking religious belief.
docs.lead_paragraph: As a business owner, I sometimes take customers out to lunch. But as an ethical vegan, I don’t want to subsidize the cruel meat and dairy industries. People seem to take my veganism as an affront to their lifestyle. Is there a way that I can, without losing customers, let them know that I just can’t underwrite killing animals? Jayn Line, Cincinnati

headline.main: I’m an Ethical Vegan. Can I Pay for a Client’s Carnivorous Meal?
headline.print_headline: Can an Ethical Vegan Pay for a Client’s Carnivorous Meal?

docs.abstract: An ordinary morning in the life of a parent dropping his son off at school assumes mythic proportions.
docs.snippet: An ordinary morning in the life of a parent dropping his son off at school assumes mythic proportions.
docs.lead_paragraph: By its very nature, the hybrid form of the prose poem alerts us to the blurring of boundaries. In Fady Joudah’s “The Scream,” an ordinary morning in the life of a parent dropping his son off at school assumes mythic proportions: A typical altercation between two kindergartners escalates into a conflict as elemental and disturbing as the parables in Genesis. For one charged moment, the well-worn rules governing domination and fear are flipped: Who is to be pitied and who judged? At what point does blame turn feral and we retreat, self-satisfied, behind our collective censure? Selected by Rita Dove

byline.original: By Fady Joudah and Rita Dove

docs.abstract: “The difference between the almost right word and the right word,” Mark Twain wrote, “is really a large matter.”
docs.snippet: “The difference between the almost right word and the right word,” Mark Twain wrote, “is really a large matter.”
docs.lead_paragraph: — From the poem “If I Shut My Eyes, What Other Doors in Me Fly Open,” by Ben Purkert, in the collection “For the Love of Endings” (Four Way Books, 2018, Page 6).

headline.main: New Sentences: From a Poem by Ben Purkert
headline.print_headline: From a Poem by Ben Purkert

docs.abstract: The social platform knows everything that happens within its walls — that’s the whole point — but it is oddly reticent when it comes to misinformation campaigns.
docs.snippet: The social platform knows everything that happens within its walls — that’s the whole point — but it is oddly reticent when it comes to misinformation campaigns.
docs.lead_paragraph: In December of last year, the Senate Intelligence Committee released two reports it had commissioned concerning Russia’s efforts to influence the 2016 election. The outline of the interference effort has always been easy to make out, but key questions about its significance — Could Russia really affect voter sentiment by posting? Did trolls really lower voter turnout in key states? — are still, in large part, matters for speculation. And the committee’s findings did little to change that.

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

docs.abstract: Roast them brown and sweet, then pickle them through and through.
docs.snippet: Roast them brown and sweet, then pickle them through and through.
docs.lead_paragraph: I think about cooking mushrooms as soon as there’s a chill in the air and I catch the scent of rain-soaked earth. But why? I was never attuned to mushroom seasons. I’ve never come home from a brisk walk in the woods like some 20th-century food writer, rain boots caked with mud, baskets full of wild varieties that I identified on sight. When I was growing up, my family bought pints and pints of brown- and white-button mushrooms all year round from the supermarket. I remember how they were squashed together and sealed tight, their graying, velveteen caps pressing obscenely against the plastic. But these mushrooms, these cheap, seasonless mushrooms, they taught me almost everything I needed to know — namely, that I loved mushrooms.

headline.main: How to Cook All the Mushrooms
headline.print_headline: How to Cook All the Mushrooms

docs.abstract: In this week’s At War newsletter: Many veterans know something that the politicians who speak for military action often do not: for those who do the fighting, war is often reduced to who is near and whatever happens.

docs.abstract: Neither human sympathy nor nature’s bounty can fill the void left by her parents’ early deaths.
docs.snippet: Neither human sympathy nor nature’s bounty can fill the void left by her parents’ early deaths.
docs.lead_paragraph: The basic rules for writing a ghazal seem straightforward — five to 15 couplets, one word repeated at the end of each stanza — but transporting this seventh-century Arabian form into a 21st-century American lyric is no mean trick. Fatimah Asghar’s brilliant offering is a dexterous blend of Old World endurance and New World bravado. Neither human sympathy nor nature’s bounty can fill the void left by her parents’ early deaths; the ferocious melancholy of that single-word refrain circles their absence as if to say: There is no escaping a loss this large — only endurance. Selected by Rita Dove

headline.main: Poem: How’d Your Parents Die Again?

byline.original: By Fatimah Asghar and Rita Dove

docs.abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on whether to help a neighbor who has become increasingly forgetful, befriending a homeless man in Tel Aviv and more.
docs.snippet: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on whether to help a neighbor who has become increasingly forgetful, befriending a homeless man in Tel Aviv and more.
docs.lead_paragraph: I live in a large co-op apartment building in Manhattan. Our staff is lovely and caring. A staff member told me that a resident is getting very forgetful and that she likes to spend her time in the lobby. I asked if she had family and was told she had only one brother in Japan. I was probably chosen as a confidante because I cared for my husband who had Alzheimer’s at home. Despite that experience, I was at a loss to give advice.

headline.main: Should I Get Involved in Helping a Neighbor With Dementia?
headline.print_headline: Should I Get Involved In Helping a Neighbor With Dementia?
